Package harrygpotter.tombola.tombolalib

TombolaLib is an home made Java class library aimed to support the development of “end user ready” software tools and applications supporting and enriching the experience of the traditional Italian game of Tombola. Generate well formed cards, collect them in sets, save to and load from files and databases, print and use them to digitally assist real Tombola games played by small or large communities of families and friends are all objectives addressed by this library.

Its purposes can quickly be summarized:

  • Provide data structures and methods help the creation of valid and well-formed cards, that is the elementary sets of 15 numbers disposed on three rows and nine columns following specific criteria.

  • Help to deal with large sets of cards, allowing the creation of such sets while reducing the numbers that inevitably are equals between different cards and thus limiting the probability of “concurrent wins” during the tombola game. TombolaLib is able to prepare cards arranged in groups of six cards using all the 90 numbers of the game, thus having zero numbers in common. These groups are called series of cards. TombolaLib provide also heuristic algorithms to generate several series of cards while limiting equal numbers between cards and cards single rows.

  • Allow for generated set of cards to be saved in files with open text formats, exported towards databases or other personal productivity tools, so you can print cards, maybe personalize the layout and use them to play.
    A dedicated class provides also method to parse html+css based templates and produce well formatted html+css file containing cards and ready to be printed using any modern browser.

  • Lively support the real play of the game, specially in large communities of families and friends, providing the environment to realize a “digital twin” of the game, where cards can be checked in real time against extracted numbers, prizes assigned, statistics evaluated, fun and “suspense generating” facts shared, etc.

Since:
1.8
Version:
1.1
Author:
Harry G. Potter (harry.g.potter@gmail.com)
  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    ITFunFigure  
    ITGameObserver
    TODO(2.0) I'm working here
    ITLogger
    Simple (maybe too simple in this release) interface used by other TombolaLib objects to trace their activities both during the card series generation phase (ITSetFactory objects) and the simulated/assisted tombola games (TGame objects). An interface is used to let TombolaLib users to provide their custom implementation of ITLogger objects. Currently the library provide a first practical implementation (see TSimpleLogger) to log on plain text files or on standard console output.
    ITSetFactory
    This is the common interface implemented by all Set of Series generation algorithm classes included in the TombolaLib library.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    TAbstractSetFactory
    Abstract class providing standard, basic implementation of common methods for the ITSetFactory interface.
    TAward
    A TAward object has a category (AMBO = two number in a row, TERNO = three number in a row, ... up to TOMBOLA, 15 numbers matched on a card) and represent a prize that cards can win playing the game. TAward objects should be prepared before a game starts and collected in a TAwardList object, where they must be arranged in ascending order to let TGame methods work properly.
    TAwardList
    Helper list class maintaining the ascending ordered list of prizes used in a tombola game.
    TBillboardCard
    TBillboardCard objects are a specialization of TCard objects, that is they are tombola cards representing the six special cards traditionally composing the tombola billboard. They all have 15 numbers each, but they are usually disposed on three rows with 5 number cells each, with no spaces. Numbers are also displaced following a criteria that is substantially different from "normals" cards.
    TCard
    A TCard instance plays the role of a single "cartella" in the traditional Italian game of Tombola. Each card is composed by 15 numbers, randomly chosen in the range [1..90] and placed on a grid of 3 rows by 9 columns, scattered so that on each row there are 4 empty spaces and 5 numbers each one belonging to a different tens.
    TCardFormatter
    This class implements a set of methods aimed to convert a TCard objects to serialized text strings, in several different formats, that can be used to be stored in files, databases or transferred over networks. Supported format are mainly based on standard text formats, such as comma separated value (CSV) strings, or JSON or XML. See also TFileFormatter, the main user of this class as it stores files cards serialized using methods here implemented.
    TCardList
    TCardList is an ArrayList specialization class helping to collect together set of cards and specifically to manage them during tombola games. During the cards generation processes, it is preferable to manage cards in groups of six of them, called series, thus TSeriesList objects target this need. During a game, instead, cards must be managed one at a time and TCardList objects are here to serve. In TCardList class are also implemented import methods and constructors to convert a TSeriesList object to a TCardList one.
    TFileFormatter
    TFileFormatter objects are responsible for serialize/de-serialize whole sets of series of cards (i.e. TSeriesList objects) in text based, both human and machine readable files.
    TFunFactEvaluator  
    TFunFigure
    TODO(2.0) Work on it!
    TGame
    TombolaGame class is a funny piece of code, where a Tombola game match can be simulated, monitored, controlled and analyzed. I like it very much! It is another piece of magic for me!
    THtmlPrinter
    This class has the responsibilities to help tombolalib library users to print on paper tombola cards. The design principles should be as simple as effective. It uses several template prepared in html+css format having inside some placeholders marked with specific character sequences. To print series of cards, placeholders are substituted by actual numbers, card labels, etc. and output file are generated in plain html+css format. Such file can thus be printed using any modern browser (i.e. Microsoft Edge, Google Chrome, Safari, Firefox, etc.). Standard format are provided to print one or more card per pages, as well as to make available different styles and graphic layouts.  User can also prepare and use their own templates, following instruction provided within the library user documentation.
    THtmlTemplate
    Object of this calla represents an HTML template used to print set of cards.
    TMakeSix
    Here some magic creation happens! TMakeSix is the class implementing the algorithm to prepare six TCard objects in a coordinated way, so that they compose a series of cards, a group of six cards using all 90 numbers of the game so they do not have duplicates.  Special thanks to the "Doc" for the great idea, years and years ago. The algorithm can be considered 'heuristic', using a random number generator.
    TNumberCell
    This is just a simple Java POJO or data object used to access tombola cards elements in a "JavaBean friendly" environment, such as a JavaServer Faces based web application. It simply stores a card number together with its gaming attributes (if it has been already matched or not, if it is a jolly number). TCard and TBillboardCard objects can provide a grid of TNumberCell object as an alternative view of themselves just to be used in such web application...
    TProgressiveSetFactory
    This class implements an heuristic algorithm that generate list of series aiming to reduce (i.e. equalize) equal numbers between each couple of cards and equal numbers between couple of single rows of the cards. Technically, generated series are added to the list only if they do not have more equal numbers by card or by row of chosen thresholds if compared to all the cards already inserted in the list.
    TSacchetto
    A TSacchetto object behaves exactly as the ballot box ('sacchetto', in Italian language) that contains the 90 figures of the Tombola game and is used to extract them one at a time before mark each number on the Tombola billboard ('Tabellone').
    TSeries
    TSeries objects represent series of six cards made using all 90 numbers of the Tombola, thus having no equal number between them. Besides, There are also methods to compare cards of a series versus cards of another series, checking how is the maximum of equal numbers between cards or rows.
    TSeriesList
    This class is used to collect series of cards, as they are generated by ITSetFactory objects. Each series of card contains 6 cards having no number in common.
    TSeriesListStats
    TSeriesListStats is an helper data structure class used to collect basic information about the "quality" of a list of series of cards object. For a given TListSeries object, a TSeriesListStats collects how many cards there are that have X numbers equal to another card within the same series list (for each X in [0, 15]) and many cards there are that have at least one row with Y numbers equals to at least one row on another card within the same series list (for each Y in [0, 5]). Maybe this is not a super-elegant class or solution an in next releases I'll find the time to improve it...
    TSimpleLogger
    TSimpleLogger is a quite simple class helping to manage the important task of take trace (that is, log) of actions made by all major TombolaLib methods. I know I could have chosen to use many beautiful, complex, logger solutions and packages already available for Java, but I preferred to reduce to the minimum external dependencies and keep things as simple as possible. Main principles to use this class and its objects follows: Each library user can prepare his own logger objects using one of the overloaded static TSimpleLogger.prepareLogger(String, ITLogger.TLogLevel, PrintStream) method available.
    TSimpleSetFactory
    TSimpleSetFactory object implements the simplest heuristic to generate series of cards. It simply generates a series of six cards at a time, without any "quality" check regarding the distribution of the numbers between the cards of different series. MaxEPC and MAxEPR values are not used, that is they can be considered as always set, respectively, to 15 and 5.
    TTombolaExamples
    This class contains some methods showing how TombolaLib classes and functionalities should be accessed and used by client Java code.
    TUtils
    General helper class for the whole TombolaLib library, containing some general constants values (i.e. hard limits for the card generation algorithms, names of default choices or default values) and some general helper methods.
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    ITFunFigure.TFigureCategory  
    ITLogger.TLogLevel
    As usual, define the discrete "levels" of importance for messages passed to ITlogger instances, in order to prioritize them and decide if they must be logged or not based on the log level set for each logger.
    ITSetFactory.TStatus
    Enum definition used to maintain the status of the generation algorithm
    TAward.TAwardStatus
    Possible award statuses used by TGame methods while checking is one or more cards have won an award following each number extraction.
    TCardFormat
    Used to specify the String format that is possible to use to visualize a card or save it in files.
    TGameResultCode
    Enum class used mainly by TGame.extractNumber(int) and TGame.resolveCandidates(int) methods to notify the result of their invocation to the TombolaLib users in a defined, controlled and finite way.
    TGameStatus
    Enum class used by TGame to maintain the status of the game, thus allowing or disabling possible game operations in each status.
    THtmlTemplate.THtmlTemplateType  
    TSeriesList.TLabelingModes
    List the supported choices you have to number cards when preparing their labels
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    TTombolaRuntimeException
    Helper class derived from RuntimeException used to identify all runtime Tombola-Specific exceptions raised by TombolaLib library methods.
